children.value: OpenSumi allows integration in two ways: Web and Electron. The extension system and its capabilities have a consistent performance on both platforms.
When developing a extension, you can quickly start the extension development environment locally using
include basic running and building scripts in
in the background during the development stage to compile the extension code in real time.
in the extension directory to start a web version of OpenSumi IDE and load the current extension into it.
Or run the development command of
# Start the OpenSumi Web version development environment
in the browser to open a web version of OpenSumi IDE.

properties.ariaLabel: command usage engine version control permalink

children.value: In OpenSumi, there are many release versions. Before developing a extension, you need to make sure that the extension API you are using is supported by the corresponding
version. You can check the current version information through the following command:
version information by the following command:
When switching versions, you only need to switch with the following command:
When encountering abnormal performance of extension functions, updating
to the latest version for testing is a more effective means of verification.

Support specifying working directory when running
This will start OpenSumi IDE with the path passed in as the
parameter and the current directory as the extension, as shown in the image below:

OpenSumi CLI does not have any built-in plug-ins. When your plug-ins rely on some capabilities of other plug-ins, you can soft-link or directly copy these plug-ins to the plug-in directory of OpenSumi CLI. The default plug-in directory is
OpenSumi CLI supports specifying the listening port of IDE Server via

properties.ariaLabel: use vs code  opensumi ide for breakpoint debugging permalink

children.value: Use VS Code / OpenSumi IDE for breakpoint debugging
The Extension Host Process is a Node.js process, and the extension code can be debugged by configuring
// A launch configuration that compiles the extension and then opens it inside a new window
// Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
// Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
// Turn on SourceMap for easy source mapping
// Specify the extension code output directory
Select Attach to Extension Host in the VS Code debug panel to use VS Code for breakpoint debugging
The principle of debugging on the local client developed based on OpenSumi is also the same, just place the configuration file under
If you need to perform breakpoint debugging in typescript source code, you need to enable Sourcemap when compiling
Currently, the desktop (Electron) version of the IDE based on the OpenSumi framework is supported as the extension runtime environment.
parameter indicates the path of the desktop IDE executable file, for example:
